<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- Calculators must not be used in this paper.- You must show all necessary working clearly.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 72, 567, 87]]<|/det|>
List of formulas 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 103, 787, 122]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\). \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 152, 675, 170]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\). \(A = \pi rl\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 200, 687, 218]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(A = 4\pi r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 244, 680, 272]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\). \(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 293, 687, 320]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 346, 655, 364]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation For the equation \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 365, 555, 397]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 440, 225, 457]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 431, 904, 472]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^n = a^n + \binom{n}{1} a^{n-1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n-2}b^2 + \dots + \binom{n}{r} a^{n-r}b^r + \dots + b^n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 477, 770, 515]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!r!}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 547, 217, 562]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 545, 675, 585]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = a + (n-1)d \\ S_n = \frac{1}{2}n(a+l) = \frac{1}{2}n\{2a+(n-1)d\}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 622, 215, 637]]<|/det|>
Geometric series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 621, 570, 700]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = ar^{n-1} \\ S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} \quad (r \neq 1) \\ S_\infty = \frac{a}{1-r} \quad (|r| < 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 733, 157, 748]]<|/det|>
Identities 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 730, 555, 780]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^2 A + \cos^2 A = 1 \\ \sec^2 A = 1 + \tan^2 A \\ \cosec^2 A = 1 + \cot^2 A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 822, 242, 838]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\) 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 816, 580, 890]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C} \\ a^2 = b^2 + c^2 - 2bc \cos A \\ \Delta = \frac{1}{2} ab \sin C\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 72, 665, 88]]<|/det|>
<form>Calculators must not be used in this paper.</form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 103, 94, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graphs of \(y = 4|x - 1|\) and \(y = |3x + 2|\), stating the intercepts with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 146, 833, 497]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 518, 146, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 517, 475, 536]]<|/det|>
Solve the inequality \(4|x - 1| \leqslant |3x + 2|.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 517, 920, 536]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 88, 880, 313]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 333, 685, 350]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = a\cos bx + c\) for \(-180^{\circ}\leqslant x\leqslant 180^{\circ}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 350, 413, 365]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(a\) , \(b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 380, 346, 397]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) , \(b\) and \(c\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 380, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 535, 94, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 535, 406, 552]]<|/det|>
The point \(A\) has coordinates \((- 3, 6)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 552, 406, 568]]<|/det|>
The point \(B\) has coordinates \((7, - 8)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 583, 737, 600]]<|/det|>
Given that the line \(AB\) is the diameter of a circle, find the equation of the circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 583, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 810, 108]]<|/det|>
The polynomial p is given by \(\mathrm{p}(x) = a^{2}x^{3} + 2ax^{2} + ax + 2\) , where \(a\) is a positive integer. It is given that \(2x + 1\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 122, 146, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 122, 310, 140]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 122, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 494, 146, 511]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 494, 327, 511]]<|/det|>
Hence factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 494, 920, 511]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 696, 146, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 696, 663, 714]]<|/det|>
Hence show that the equation \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 0\) has only one real root.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 695, 920, 714]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 146, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 78, 767, 100]]<|/det|>
Write \(2x^{2} - 2x + 3\) in the form \(a(x + b)^{2} + c\) , where \(a\) , \(b\) and \(c\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 104, 100, 128]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 263, 530, 284]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{f}(x) = 2x^{2} - 2x + 3\) , for \(x \leqslant p\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 297, 148, 316]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 297, 636, 317]]<|/det|>
Write down the greatest value of \(p\) for which f has an inverse.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 297, 920, 316]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 420, 146, 439]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 420, 532, 440]]<|/det|>
Using this value of \(p\) , write down the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 420, 920, 440]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 560, 148, 578]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 541, 580]]<|/det|>
Using this value of \(p\) , find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 560, 920, 580]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 83, 94, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 524, 103]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\tan \theta = \frac{\sqrt{5}}{5}\) and \(180^{\circ} < \theta < 360^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 115, 146, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 115, 343, 132]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\cos \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 115, 920, 133]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 301, 146, 319]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 301, 339, 319]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\sin \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 301, 920, 319]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 456, 146, 473]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 456, 405, 473]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\sec \theta + \cot \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 479, 697, 510]]<|/det|>
Give your answer in the form \(\frac{a + b\sqrt{c}}{\sqrt{5}}\) , where \(a\) , \(b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 82, 905, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 432, 918, 470]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = \frac{5}{x + 1} +2\) and part of the line \(y = 2x + 1\) intersecting at the point \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 484, 146, 502]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 484, 361, 502]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 484, 918, 502]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 472, 87]]<|/det|>
Find the exact area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 918, 87]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 485, 90]]<|/det|>
The first term of a geometric progression is 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 87, 574, 106]]<|/det|>
This geometric progression has a positive common ratio \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 119, 535, 136]]<|/det|>
The first term of an arithmetic progression is also 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 134, 625, 152]]<|/det|>
This arithmetic progression has a negative common difference \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 165, 845, 198]]<|/det|>
The second term of the geometric progression is the same as the fourth term of the arithmetic progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 195, 915, 212]]<|/det|>
The third term of the geometric progression is the same as the sixth term of the arithmetic progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 227, 148, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 227, 364, 246]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(r\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 228, 920, 246]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 725, 149, 743]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 725, 682, 743]]<|/det|>
Determine whether the geometric progression has a sum to infinity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 725, 920, 743]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 83, 104, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 79, 467, 101]]<|/det|>
The point \(P\) lies on the curve \(\quad y = \left(5x + 2\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 100, 325, 116]]<|/det|>
The \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) is 5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 115, 693, 131]]<|/det|>
The normal to the curve at \(P\) intersects the line \(x + y = 11\) at the point \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 131, 625, 147]]<|/det|>
The point \(R\) is the reflection of \(Q\) in the tangent to the curve at \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 161, 322, 177]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 161, 920, 178]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 453, 88]]<|/det|>
Continuation of working space for Question 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 102, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 92, 833, 314]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 335, 411, 352]]<|/det|>
In the diagram, \(\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{a}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OB} = \mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|>
The point \(M\) is the midpoint of \(OB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 373, 395, 390]]<|/det|>
The point \(N\) is such that \(\overrightarrow{ON} = 3\overrightarrow{NA}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 393, 472, 410]]<|/det|>
The lines \(BN\) and \(AM\) intersect at the point \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 411, 396, 428]]<|/det|>
\(\overrightarrow{BX} = \lambda \overrightarrow{BN},\) where \(\lambda\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 430, 396, 447]]<|/det|>
\(\overrightarrow{MX} = \mu \overrightarrow{MA},\) where \(\mu\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 462, 146, 479]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 462, 410, 479]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 462, 910, 479]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 78, 410, 96]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{OX}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\) , \(\mathbf{b}\) and \(\mu\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 96]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 498, 144, 516]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 498, 420, 516]]<|/det|>
